far.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: Since I changed jobs, I have to travel further to get to work.
Let’s see who can jump the furthest!
The lake is about 4 miles away, but we probably won’t get that far (=won’t go as far as that place).
If you want to go further afield, there are bicycles for hire.
The children don’t go far from home.
She wants to move as far away from here as possible.
They could hear the sound of water not far away.
He lives further down the street.
Many birds fly further south in the autumn.
The plains stretched for as far as the eye could see (=all the distance you could see).
far.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: used when asking the distance between two places, or when talking about the distance between two places
far.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: How far is it to the station?
The man didn’t say how far it was to the next town.
far.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to a place or point, but not beyond it
far.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: They managed to get as far as the Spanish border.
far.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: very much, or to a great degree
far.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: We’ve kept the original features of the house as far as possible (=as much as possible).
How far do those old, outdated laws affect today’s legislation?
His style was far removed (=very different) from that of Picasso.
The new system is far better than the old one.
There are a far greater number of women working in television than twenty years ago.
I enjoyed it far more than I expected.
That’s far too much to pay.
It would take me far too long to explain.
I guessed it would cost $100 and it was $110, so I was not far out.
He bought it for a price that was far beyond  (=much more than) its real value.
The teacher said that her writing skills were far below average.
far.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: used to talk about how much progress someone makes, or how much effect something has
far.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: He started to explain, but he didn’t get far (=he did not succeed in saying very much) before Mary interrupted him.
Many people felt that the new law did not go far enough (=did not have a big enough effect, so that more needed to be done).
They had got as far as painting the kitchen.
get as far as doing something
far.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: a long time in the past or the future, or a long time into a particular period
far.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: The first petrol-driven car was produced as far back as 1883.
We talked far into the night.
They want to plan much further ahead than the next few years.
far.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: far
a long distance – used mainly in negatives and questions, or after ‘too’, ‘so’, and ‘as’
It’s not far to the airport from here.
Have you driven far?
The ship was so far away we could hardly see it.
a long way
a long distance from somewhere. This is the most common way of talking about long distances, except in negatives and questions when far is also common
You must be tired – you’ve come a long way.
It’s a long way down from the top of the cliff.
I can’t see things that are a long way away.
miles
a very long way
We hiked miles.
The school is miles away from where I live.
in the distance
a long way from where you are now – used when talking about things that seem small or sounds that seem quiet because they are a long way away
Dogs were barking somewhere in the distance.
distant
used about something that is a long distance from where you are now, and looks small or sounds quiet
By now, the plane was just a distant speck in the sky.
the rumble of distant thunder
faraway
a very long distance from where you are now
a traveller from a faraway land
His voice sounded faraway.
He told us stories about the faraway countries he had visited.
remote
a remote place is a long distance from other places, and few people go there
The helicopter crashed in a remote part of the country.
remote holiday destinations
isolated
an isolated place is a long distance from other towns, buildings, or people, and there is very little communication with surrounding places
isolated rural areas of Nepal
Occasionally we passed through a small isolated village.
If you travel to isolated areas, make sure you have a good guide.
off the beaten track
a place that is off the beaten track is a long distance from the places where people usually go, and often seems interesting and different because of this
She likes to go to places that are a bit off the beaten track.
far.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: We can walk to my house from here. It isn’t far.
You could see the mountains in the far distance.
